msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This combined Psalter and Book of Hours, written in Dutch around 1450-1465, has been divided into two volumes at a later date (likely in the late seventeenth or early eighteenth century). The Psalter, arranged for fortnightly reading (fols. 12r-193v), is the translation begun by Geert Groote and completed by Johan Scutken (d. 1423). The Psalter, with early numerals added in the margins, is followed by the Canticles and Litany, and Augustine's prologue to the Psalms. There follows the Hours of Eternal Wisdom, the long Hours of the Cross, the Office of the Dead, and the unusual Hours of the Pentecost. A single folio with instructions for use has been added in a contemporary hand (fol. 281). The seven miniatures included in this manuscript (only one of which is in the first volume) were painted by one of the few Netherlandish illuminators for whom we have a name: Antonis Rogiersz Uten Broec, who was mainly active in Utrecht in the 1450s and 1460s. All seven miniatures have panel border surrounds and are blank on their recto sides.

respStmt.persName: Antonis Rogiersz uten Broec (Master of the Boston City of God)

msItem.title: Canticles followed by Litany, translation of Geert Groote
Saint Augustine's Prologue in praise of the Psalms, in Dutch
msItem.incipit: Dit sanc der psalmen heylicht dat lichaem Het verciert der siel... [fol. 211r]
msItem.explicit: Mer die sanc der psalmen toent dat ewighe lof godes ende die oneyndelike glorie. [fol. 212v]

msItem.title: Hours of Eternal Wisdom, translation of Geert Groote: Preface
Hours of Eternal Wisdom, translation of Geert Groote
Long Hours of the Cross, translation of Geert Groote
Office of the Dead, short form, translation of Geert Groote
Hours of the Pentecost (beginning with Vesper and Compline)
Prayer to the Trinity, "Van heylighen drieuolditheit"
msItem.explicit: Ende onfanc minen gheest in die throen dijns ewighen rijcs. Amen. [fol. 280r]

msItem.title: Psalm readings for certain spiritual needs, and for Wednesday through Friday

supportDesc.extent: i+152+i; 140 x 93 mm bound to 147 x 97 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

layoutDesc.layout: Edges trimmed; one column of twenty-one lines, ruled in brown ink (written area: 92 x 62 mm)

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Two scribes: scribe two, fol. 281r-v only

decoDesc.decoNote: Six full-page inserted miniatures with full foliate borders, five six-to-eight-line initials with full foliate border, several three-to-six-line initials with spray extensions, two-line gold initials throughout, one-line initials in alternating red and blue throughout
130vFull-page miniature, Virgin and Child with adoring nun
214vFull-page miniature, Saint Catherine of Alexandria and Saint Barbara

binding.p: Late-seventeenth- or early-eighteenth-century, mottled calf, gilt edges, spines decorated with gold-tooled panels and labeled PSALMEN TOM II, red edges; in case

history.provenance: Gaspar-Joseph de Servais (1735-1807), Mechelin (Malines), Belgium; his sale Mechlin, Messieurs Du Trieu, October 3, 1808, p. 31; lot. 354; Oliver Henry Perkins (Des Moines, Iowa); his sale New York, Anderson Galleries, March 23, 1926, lot 561; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; inside front cover, signature of Gaspar-Joseph de Servais and bookplate of Oliver Henry Perkins
